results.title: Sticks and stones
results.creator_credit: Jan Padgett, George Johnson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Sticks and stones is an award-winning Canadian documentary aimed at promoting discussion of gay and gender-related issues between children, their teachers and parents. It uses the experiences, ideas and opinions of children themselves, some with gay parents, to examine non-traditional families, gender stereotyping and gender roles. Children are encouraged to find the reasons behind bullying and name-calling, and come up with their own solutions to these problems. Sticks and Stones is suitable for children aged 5 to 12; there is a related title In Other Words for older audiences.

results.title: Stories and songs of the people: the second stage
results.creator_credit: Johnnie Aseron, Fiona Cochrane, Film Victoria and F-Reel Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Participants in the Stories and Songs of the People weekend tell their personal stories and provide a perspective on living in a world dominated by white culture. The struggles of indigenous peoples in Australia and some other parts of the world are explored through these individual experiences. A selection of music and songs performed during the weekend provide a backdrop to the discussion.

results.title: Stopover
results.brief_description: Depicts a traveller at a stopover in a bus terminal who demonstrates the possibility of living gourmet style while travelling by Greyhound bus. Raises important questions pertaining to outright theft, consumerism, etc.

results.title: Stevie
results.brief_description: Born in Yorkshire, England in 1902, Florence Margaret “Stevie” Smith began writing poetry in her twenties. Her father left when she was very young and her mother died when she was a teenager, leaving Stevie and her sister under the loving care of their spinster aunt. Stevie was officially recognised with the Chomondeley Award for Poetry in 1966 and the Queen’s Gold Medal for Poetry in 1969. She died of a brain tumor in 1971. The film “Stevie” is literally based on Hugh Whitemore’s play and the works of Stevie Smith to present an historical and biographical look at Stevie’s life. It explores the loving relationship between Stevie (Glenda Jackson) and her Aunt (Mona Washbourne), the romantic liaisons in Stevie’s life, and the eventual fame that her poetic writings bring, using flashbacks and direct dialogue with the audience by Stevie and “The Man” (Trevor Howard). This is very much a stage play on film with not a lot of cinematic expression or extravagant landscapes, confined most of the time to the living room scenes of the house where Stevie and her Aunt dwell. However, it is the literary merit and the art of language which perhaps give this film its appeal, not to mention the excellent performances by some of Britain’s most highly acclaimed actors. Cast also includes Alex McCowan. Winner of many awards including Montreal Film Festival, New York Film Critics Circle Awards, and nominated for BAFTA and Golden Globe Awards.

results.title: Turnover
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
Deals with the problem of how far should a supervisor delve into the personal life and problems of staff in order to help with personal problems. Cast includes Jack Thompson.

results.title: Stirring
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The film has been produced to demonstrate how a teacher approaches the controversial issue of the use of corporal punishment in schools. It includes class discussions with the boys in a high school in New South Wales, role playing and discussions with other teachers and with people outside the school. The boys also raise issues such as the communication barriers existing between teachers and students, the repressive aspects of school life, and the possibility of change.

results.title: Stir
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Richard Brennan, New South Wales Film Corporation and Smiley Films
results.brief_description: A tense, realistic Australian drama which examines the barbarity and cruelty that exists within an Australian jail for male prisoners. Bryan Brown stars as a young but experienced convict determined to protest against the mindless, and often dehumanising, rules and limitations placed on prisoners. The script-writer, Bob Jewson, was a prisoner at Bathurst Goal in 1974 and he has based his script for “Stir” on the events and personalities which led to the infamous rioting at that institution. “Stir” culminates in a similar explosive finish. Cast also includes Max Phipps, Dennis Miller, Gary Waddell, Phil Motherwell, Edward Robshaw, Michael Gow and Robert ‘Tex’ Morton. Written by Bob Jewson. Photography by Geoff Burton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Wallace, Richard Brennan, New South Wales Film Corporation and Smiley Films

results.title: Steps of the ballet
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Alexander Shaw and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: Deals with the creation of a ballet. The basic positions, movements and steps are demonstrated. The dancers’ steps are explained by Robert Helpmann, famous ballet dancer and choreographer. The film ends with the presentation of a new ballet to show how the arts of dancing, music and painting join together in its creation. Featured dancers include Alexander Grant (New Zealand), Elaine Fifield, Gordon Hamilton (Australia), Gerd Larsen, Peter Wright (United Kingdom), with Joan Harris (United Kingdom) as Ballet Mistress. Narrated by Robert Helpmann.

results.title: Still killing us softly
results.creator_credit: Margaret Margaret Lazarus and Cambridge Documentary Films
results.brief_description: In this program, Jean Kilbourne examines images in advertising. She explores the relationship of media images to actual problems in society, such as the channelling of men and women into traditional roles and occupations, economic discrimination against women, the sexual abuse of children, rape and other forms of violence, pornography, sexual harassment, teenage pregnancy and eating disorders.
